Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They provide in-depth guidance on a critical task where mistakes could have serious consequences.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my hands trembling as I reread the message from my cousin. “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means a lot to Grandma.” My family expected me to step up, to honor our traditions and show respect for the generations before me. I could already picture my parents’ proud faces, the weight of their hopes pressing on my shoulders.

But my phone buzzed again—this time, a desperate text from my mentee at work. “I’m stuck. If I mess this up, the whole project could fail. Can you walk me through it?” As a mentor, I was supposed to be available, to guide and support, especially when the stakes were high. I knew how much my mentee depended on me, how much trust they placed in my experience.

The ceremony and the project overlapped. I felt torn, pulled in two directions by people who needed me for different reasons. My heart ached with the fear of letting someone down, of failing to live up to the expectations that defined who I was—both as a child and as a mentor.
